Some popular tales are subjects of more finished performances: one instance is

noticed in my treatise on Sanscrit &c poetry in the Asiatic Researches.
I entirely concur in opinion with you that a Catalogue raisonné of a collection of Indian Manuscripts is a work much wanted – In the conviction of its utility I once began such a Catalogue of my own Collection; but want of leisure prevented my persevering in it when I could command requisite assistance of a librarian.
There is in England a considerable number of Sanscrit manuscripts collected by the late
Chief Judge of the Supreme Court at

; which his heirs were desirous of selling some time ago, & probably still are so. It was offered for sale in more than one quarter, with a condition that the collection should not be scattered but kept together, & continue to bear Sir Robertʼs name. Whether that or any other restriction would now be proposed, I cannot positively say: but after my return from abroad I will tender to you my services to ascertain all particulars you may be desirous of being furnished with.
[3]
